verses.text: I love the LORD because he hears my voice and my cries for mercy.
verses.comment: The psalmist begins with deep personal gratitude for God's attentive love, reflecting a close relationship between the believer and God.

verses.text: Because he has inclined his ear to me, I will call on him as long as I live.
verses.comment: Inclining the ear is an image of God’s readiness to act in mercy, inviting lifelong prayer and dependence.

verses.text: The cords of death surrounded me, and the anguish of the grave took hold of me; I found trouble and sorrow.
verses.comment: The psalmist expresses deep affliction and a sense of being overwhelmed by death, echoing language that anticipates the suffering servant (cf. Isaiah 53).

verses.text: Then I called upon the name of the LORD: 'O LORD, I pray, deliver my soul!'
verses.comment: The calling upon the name of the LORD points to the dynamics of faith: trouble leads to sincere prayer, reflecting the necessity of turning to God in distress.

verses.text: Gracious is the LORD and righteous; yes, our God is compassionate.
verses.comment: God’s character—grace, justice, and compassion—are central, and later fulfilled perfectly in Christ (John 1:14).

verses.text: The LORD preserves the simple; I was brought low, and he saved me.
verses.comment: God’s protection of the humble is a theme echoed in the beatitudes (Matthew 5:3). The word 'simple' refers to sincerity and humility, not ignorance.

verses.text: Return, O my soul, to your rest, for the LORD has dealt bountifully with you.
verses.comment: The soul finds rest in God’s goodness, foreshadowing Christ’s promise of rest for the weary (Matthew 11:28).

verses.text: For you have delivered my soul from death, my eyes from tears, my feet from stumbling.
verses.comment: The deliverance from danger and sorrow prefigures resurrection and the ultimate hope in Christ’s victory over death.

verses.text: I will walk before the LORD in the land of the living.
verses.comment: To ‘walk before the LORD’ means living a life pleasing to God, anticipating the Christian life lived in Christ (Galatians 2:20).

verses.text: I believed, therefore I spoke; I was greatly afflicted.
verses.comment: This verse is cited by Paul (2 Corinthians 4:13) to describe the faith that leads to testimony even in suffering—faith is foundational to witness.

verses.text: I said in my alarm, 'All men are liars.'
verses.comment: The psalmist expresses human frailty and the unreliability of people's promises compared to God's faithfulness.

verses.text: What shall I give back to the LORD for all his benefits to me?
verses.comment: Thanksgiving is a fitting response to grace; this builds to sacrificial worship, connecting subtly to the idea of offering thanks in action, not only words.

verses.text: I will lift up the cup of salvation and call on the name of the LORD.
verses.comment: The 'cup of salvation' is a powerful image. In the New Testament, Jesus gives the cup as a new covenant (see Matthew 26:27). Some early interpreters see a connection with the Eucharist, a perpetual thanksgiving.

verses.text: I will pay my vows to the LORD in the presence of all his people.
verses.comment: A vow fulfilled in public worship shows faith lived communally, not in isolation—prefiguring corporate, liturgical worship.

verses.text: Precious in the sight of the LORD is the death of his saints.
verses.comment: God treasuring the death of his 'saints' (holy ones) anticipates the value of martyrdom and eternal life, echoed in Revelation 14:13.

verses.text: O LORD, truly I am your servant; I am your servant, the son of your maidservant. You have loosed my bonds.
verses.comment: Claiming identity as God’s servant, freed from bondage, presents a spiritual truth realized in Christian initiation (cf. John 8:36, Galatians 4:7), experienced personally and through spiritual lineage.

verses.text: I will offer to you the sacrifice of thanksgiving and call on the name of the LORD.
verses.comment: Thanksgiving offerings are described as sacrifices, prefiguring the Christian call to offer spiritual sacrifices (Romans 12:1).

verses.text: I will pay my vows to the LORD in the presence of all his people,
verses.comment: Repetition of public vow-keeping emphasizes the necessity of communal faith and worship, not just private belief.

verses.text: in the courts of the house of the LORD, in your midst, O Jerusalem. Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: Worship in the temple courts points to ordered, visible worship that takes place in the heart of God’s people (Jerusalem). In Christian understanding, the fullness of worship is realized in the community gathered around God's altar.
